results.title: Not for hire
results.creator_credit: David Caesar, Georgia Allen and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
Taxi driving is a competitive business but you can’t beat it for a sense of freedom, say the drivers. However, not all the drivers are in the game out of freedom of choice. Many are overseas immigrants whose professional qualifications proved unacceptable in Australia - they had to make a living somehow.

results.title: A Long time dream
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
The diversity of remote Aboriginal tribes is vast and complex. Between them they speak fifty languages, live in 1,000 communities and number some 54,000 people. This program looks at some of the ways these communities have related to white society. Some communities live a superficially western style of life, yet cling to their tribal laws and customs. Others have developed social problems such as alcoholism by discarding their traditional lifestyles, some have returned to a traditional life-style and yet others are using western technology, such as radio broadcasting to reinforce and spread their own culture.

results.title: Skin of the earth
results.creator_credit: Frank Rijavec, Film and Television Institute (W.A.) and Excalibur Nominees
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
John Thomson, a retired forester from Western Australia, and a committed conservationist gives his view on the destruction of the Karri forests and the subsequent effects on the land in Western Australia. His views are reiterated by Norman Lockyer, a farmer and by Dr. Chittleborough who failed in his attempt to put through a comprehensive State Conservation Strategy. Although largely pessimistic in its outlook the program does suggest that attitudes are changing to the hitherto wasteful and destructive forestry and agricultural practices.

results.title: Al fresco
results.creator_credit: Mario Andreacchio, Barbara Mariotti and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
In Adelaide’s Al Fresco Gelataria the young and the single meet friends, watch the passing scene of Rundle St. or strike up new relationships. Part of Adelaide’s thriving cafe society, the patrons of Al Fresco talk about their reasons for coming there, their attitude to peer groups and peer group pressure and how they relate to each other.

results.creator_credit: Margaret Haselgrove, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service and Australia. Office of Multicultural Affairs
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
Cornish descendants, a tourist guide and a historian talk about the contribution that the Cornish miners made to the development of the South Australian copper mines at Burra and Moonta. We also look at some of their traditions which have been handed down from generation to generation in this ‘Little Cornwall”

results.title: Saturday school
results.creator_credit: Rick Cavaggion, Georgia Allan and SBS-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
Ethnic language schools have been a part of Australia’s educational history since the 1850’s. However, until the advent of multiculturalism in the early 1970s, ethnic language schools were treated with disdain by the mainstream educational authorities who believed in assimilation programs for migrants rather than a continuing of cultural and linguistic ethnic traditions. In this video, the South Australian model for ethnic schools is investigated, including sources of financial assistance; the important work the schools do in maintaining respect for langauge and culture; and the role the schools now have in teaching new languages to children from English-speaking backgrounds.

results.title: What's mad to you? Part 1: Glimpses from psychiatrists
results.creator_credit: Barbara A. Chobocky, Margaret Smith and SBS-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
The first in a two-part series, this program looks at the stigma associated with mental illness, particularly in relation to migrants who have different value systems. A number of psychologists and psychiatrists from a wide variety of ethnic backgrounds talk about the problems as they see it. The patient’s point of view is also presented by a small group who talk about how they overcame their resistance to seeking psychiatric help.

results.title: Chinese Diggers
results.creator_credit: Teck Tan, Margaret Smith and SBS-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
A Prizewinner at the 31st International Film and TV Festival of New York this program looks at Australia’s attitude to Chinese Australians who wanted to join the Armed Forces to assist in the defence of Australia during the Second World War. In examining the stories of those interviewed a number of issues are brought to light. The video is accompanied by Teacher’s notes and workcards.

results.title: A Local stranger: Claude Beach in Julia Creek
results.creator_credit: Mark Shields-Brown, Barbara Mariotti and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
Claude Beach is a travelling portrait photographer touring the outback towns of Australia. A German immigrant, he has been on the move for the last twenty five or thirty years, travelling fifteen times all around Australia. This fragment of his solitary life shows him setting up shop in Julia Creek and drumming up business amongst the townsfolk there.

results.title: Beyond the ivory towers
results.creator_credit: Karla Fritis, Margaret Smith and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
This program looks at artists and political protest, using as a focus the exhibition “Towers of torture” held at Sydney University’s Tin Shed Gallery in 1988. Artists, including Bernard Smith, Ruth Waller, Clem Milward, Bruce Petty and George Gittoes had been asked to contribute works which protested Alan Bond’s involvement with the Pinochet regime. As well as discussing the specific issue of Chile, Professor Bernard Smith and art critic Charles Merewether discuss the role of the artist in social and political protest, with particular reference to Australian art.
